section.title: General troubleshooting
section.para: If your network connection is not working properly, there are a few tools that can be used to help diagnose the problem.

section.title: Get information about the current connection
section.para: To get information about your network connection and network devices, you have two options:

listitem.para: Using NetworkManager
Click on the NetworkManager icon
Select Connection Information. If this is disabled, it is likely there is no active connection. Try using ifconfig to find out more.
Each active connection will have its own tab where you can find relevant connection information
Using ifconfig
Open a terminal (&terminal;), type the command ifconfig then press the &key;Enter key.

ifconfig will show you extensive information about your connection, including logical or connection name(s) (e.g. enp3s0) in the left column, IP address in the inet addr column and the MAC address for your device in the HWaddr column

section.title: Check if a connection is working properly
section.para: A reliable method to check if a connection is working properly is to ping another computer on the network or the Internet.
To check if your computer is connected to the Internet, open a terminal (&terminal;), type the command ping -c 3 www.xubuntu.org then press the &key;Enter key.

The computer will then attempt to contact www.xubuntu.org three times and display the results. The ping statistics display the number of packets transmitted, how many packets were received, the percentage of packet loss, and the total time spent.

listitem.para: 0% packet loss indicates that your computer is connected to the Internet
Greater than 0% but less than 100% packet loss indicates that your computer has a poor connection to the Internet or a poor wireless signal
100% packet loss indicates that your computer has a very bad connection, or is connected to an access point or router that is not connected to the Internet

section.para: If you get an error message that says "www.xubuntu.org can not be found" or "unknown host", then your computer is probably not connected to the Internet or is unable to reach a Domain Name System (DNS) server.

section.title: Wireless troubleshooting
section.para: This section covers some common problems faced with wireless support. There is much more information available in the Community Help Wiki.

note.para: Please note that the steps in this troubleshooting guide are designed to be carried out in the order shown, unless you are pointed to a different subsection.

section.title: Check that the device is turned on
section.para: Many wireless network devices can be turned on or off. Check for a hardware switch or a keyboard function key to turn the wireless device on.
If the device is turned on, continue to the next topic.

section.title: Check if the device is recognized
section.para: Open a terminal (&terminal;), type the command sudo lshw -C network, then press the &key;Enter key. You will see some output, along with the words CLAIMED, UNCLAIMED, ENABLED or DISABLED.

listitem.para: CLAIMED indicates that a driver is loaded but not functioning. Continue to .
UNCLAIMED indicates that there is no driver loaded. Continue to .
ENABLED indicates that the driver is installed and working. Continue to section .
DISABLED indicates the driver is installed, but disabled. Continue to .

section.title: Using Windows wireless drivers
section.para: Xubuntu supports a system known as NDISWrapper. This allows you to use a Windows wireless device driver under Xubuntu. To start using NDISWrapper:

listitem.para: Obtain the Windows driver for your network device and locate the file that ends with .inf
Install the &package;ndisgtk package
Go to &wm-settings-ndisgtk;
Select Install new driver
Choose the location of your Windows .inf file and click Install
Click OK

section.title: Checking for a connection to the router
section.para: Open a terminal (&terminal;), type the command iwconfig then press the &key;Enter key.
If the ESSID for your router is displayed, there may be a problem with ACPI support. Boot Xubuntu with the pci=noacpi option.

section.title: Advanced troubleshooting
section.para: The following troubleshooting methods are a bit more technical. Please try these methods only if the above methods failed.

section.title: Checking IP assignment
section.para: Open a terminal (&terminal;), type the command ifconfig then press the &key;Enter key. If there is an IP address displayed, continue to .
From the terminal enter the following command, replacing enp3s0 with the name of the connection shown in the output from the ifconfig command: sudo dhclient enp3s0

listitem.para: If you receive a message that says bound to xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx continue to
If not, reboot the system

section.title: Check Domain Name Servers (DNS)
section.para: Open a terminal (&terminal;), type the command nmcli device show then press the &key;Enter key. Look for the entries under IP4.DNS

To check if the listed DNS works, open a terminal (&terminal;), type the command dig xubuntu.org then press the &key;Enter key. If you see the word NOERROR in the header section of the output, your DNS is working.
If there are no DNS settings listed, contact your Internet Service Provider (ISP), and find out your primary and secondary domain name servers.
